raw: The occasion and return byway of le Siberian Railway. The members that Pussi are of my frieds if this proposals not practicall wish my tori will corme home with Hi Liang Tulfen the future or designa Ted Sinister og Horeignafairs at Pitung, wie now in the Hates and will retura tela with my loum Ek Tong kaison within me enout Tie. This sony stress desire I have ny taras retum, soon after his camination and have his vacation at home, Please provide him with the browly I remited and oblige Yours lust Teens PS Kkwan. In case hr Tong Kai Son and Aldiang Pun Yen will not be able to come back during my Dous vacation please don't wait for them, and make arrangement to come straight back. Jam afraid my You will not be able to witness the Coronation féle because of the Crowd and people have to pay heavily for a good pisikin to view the hrocinion to tus reason I think its wise to deslease with the trup tingland and not to come back by Liberia wik That Party, but to return by way of Japan whiök i a cheaper voyage

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Handwritten letter stating that a draft for $500 gold has been sent a month ago for his son, Sung Sing Kwan. Dr. Kwan asks that Stearns send his son back to China for three months by way of England to witness the coronation of King George with the Chinese Special Mission, and to return by the Siberial Railway. He proposes an alternative to this plan: that his son would travel with H.E. Lien Tun Yen (Minister of Foreign Affairs in Peking) and Mr. Tong Kaison, In the postscript to the letter Dr. Kwan writes that the coronation will be crowded and because of the high cost to do so. If the , he requests that his son return directly, by way of Japan, since it is cheaper.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
